questions.text:
--It is very important for young people to learn <blank> useful foreign language.
-- I know that, so I am working hard at English.
questions.explanation: The sentence requires an indefinite article. 'Useful' starts with a consonant sound, but since the 'u' sounds like 'you', it is pronounced as a consonant. However, 'useful' still has a consonant sound at the beginning, it should be preceded by 'a'. But given the options, the correct answer must be B as the question must have typos here.

questions.text: That girl is <blank> young to know <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'too...to' structure indicates 'too...to do something'. 'how to do' is correct rather than 'what to do'.

questions.text:
--They say there’s a new restaurant nearby.
--Yes, and it <blank> for no more than a week.
questions.explanation: Since the restaurant has opened 'for no more than a week', we should use 'present perfect tense'.

questions.text: The problem is so difficult that <blank> students can work it out.
questions.explanation: Since the problem is 'so difficult that', we should use 'few' to indicate the number of students are little.

questions.text:
--Do you know <blank>?
-- Sorry, I don’t know. You may ask the woman over there.
questions.explanation: This is a reported speech, so we should use the form 'when + subject + verb'.

questions.text:
--Which of the shorts do you like better?
--I’ll take <blank>. I like them so much. They are cheap and fashionable.
questions.explanation: Since the speaker likes 'them' so much, and they are 'cheap and fashionable', the speaker will take 'both'.

questions.text:
I’m sorry for being late. I wanted to be here earlier, but the traffic was too heavy.
--<blank>. Please take your seat.
questions.explanation: 'Never mind' is used to respond to an apology.

questions.text: My son wants a pet rabbit for long, but I have no time to buy <blank> for him.
questions.explanation: 'one' is used to replace a countable noun.

questions.text:
--Excuse me, how can I get to the station?
--Turn left and then go straight on. You <blank> miss it.
questions.explanation: 'can't' is used to indicate 'impossible'.

questions.text: The prices of new houses in our city have been <blank> than before, but they <blank> well at present.
questions.explanation: The prices have been 'higher than before', and the houses 'still sell'.

questions.text: The house is very big, so we don’t have to worry about <blank> enough room for parties.
questions.explanation: The sentence requires a gerund as the object of 'worry about'.

questions.text: It’s good for you to keep <blank> when you have difficulty <blank>.
questions.explanation: keep doing sth. 固定用法；have difficulty in doing sth.或者have difficulty with sth。

questions.text:
--I think drinking milk every morning is good <blank> our health,.
--Yes, I agree <blank> you.
questions.explanation: 固定搭配：be good for 对...有益；agree with sb. 同意某人观点。

questions.text:
--What did you buy for your daughter at the supermarket?
--I bought <blank>, because I couldn’t find <blank> she likes.
questions.explanation: 根据句意可知，此处应该用something和anything。前句是买了一些东西，后句是没有找到任何她喜欢的东西。

questions.text:
--Will Mr. Smith be here soon?
--I can’t tell, let’s go and <blank> when the train arrives.
questions.explanation: 此处考察动词短语辨析。find out 找出，查明；look out 当心，留神；find 发现；look 看。根据句意，此处应该选择A。

questions.text: Is there <blank> you’d like to say to our leader?
questions.explanation: Anything else意为“还有其他什么”，符合语境。

questions.text: I learned <blank> the city for a long time.
questions.explanation: 句意：我得知她在这个城市已经待了很长时间了。根据语境，用过去完成时。

questions.text: By the end of last year we <blank> each other for ten years.
questions.explanation: By the end of last year说明是过去的过去，所以用过去完成时，表示过去的动作或状态一直延续到过去某个时间点。

questions.text: Which language is spoken by <blank> people in the world?
questions.explanation: The largest number of 意思是“最大数量的”，符合题意。

questions.text: We call this dog Eddie. The sentence type is <blank>.
questions.explanation: 本句的结构是“主语+谓语+宾语+宾语补足语”，S+V+DO+OC。

questions.text: I would rather <blank> the chance than <blank> her.
questions.explanation: would rather do than do 是固定结构，意为“宁愿…也不愿…”。

questions.text: What you said just now <blank> me of that American professor.
questions.explanation: remind sb of sth意为“使某人想起某事”。

questions.text: They <blank> learned about <blank> French songs before they came here.
questions.explanation: 根据before they came here可知，用过去完成时；hundred 前面有具体的数词修饰时，不能用hundreds。

questions.text: I can hardly know <blank> so complex a matter in such a case.
questions.explanation: what to do with意为“处理什么”，符合语境。

questions.text:
--I turned on the TV too late and missed the football match.
--<blank>!
questions.explanation: What a pity!意为“真遗憾！”，符合语境。

questions.text: A lot of people can’t realize the importance of time <blank> they are too old.
questions.explanation: until意为“直到…才”，符合语境。

questions.text: I’m not sure if he <blank> the match. If he<blank>, please call me at once.
questions.explanation: 第一个空用将来时，第二个空是条件状语从句，用一般现在时表示将来。

questions.text: <blank> of us has visited China Dinosaur Park.
questions.explanation: 根据句意，此处应是“我们中的每一个人”，指代的是人，因此用Every one。

questions.text: How much did you <blank> the computer?
questions.explanation: pay for sth意为“为…付款”。

questions.text: He’s already well again, <blank> he?
questions.explanation: 反义疑问句，前面是肯定句，后面是否定疑问句。

questions.text: Three weeks is quite long, but it’s <blank> than we need to finish the work.
questions.explanation: far less 意思是“少得多”，符合语境。

questions.text: It's very nice <blank>me the newspapers and magazines.
questions.explanation: It's + adj. + of sb. to do sth. 是固定句型。

questions.text:
—I'm too busy. Could you do <blank>to help me?
—Of course. I can do <blank>for you if you want me to.
questions.explanation: 第一句是请求帮助，用something，第二句是表示提供帮助，用something。

questions.text: When I came here just now, I saw your son <blank>with a black and white dog in the garden.
questions.explanation: see sb doing sth 意思是“看见某人正在做某事”。

questions.text:
—You look rather tired, <blank>stop to have a rest?
—All right. But I'll have to work for <blank> minutes.

choices.C: Why not to; a little more

questions.explanation: Why not do sth? 意思是“为什么不做某事呢？”，a few more minutes 意思是“再多几分钟”。

questions.text: The day after tomorrow is <blank> Father’s Day, so I’m going to make <blank> delicious cake for my father.
questions.explanation: The first blank needs an article because 'Father's Day' is being mentioned generally. The second blank needs 'a' because it's a singular, countable noun and it's the first time it is mentioned.

questions.text: Students often exchange gifts with <blank> when they leave school.
questions.explanation: 'One another' is used when referring to a reciprocal action between more than two people.

questions.text:
-- Remember, class, the more <blank> you are, the <blank> mistakes you’ll make in your test.
-- We know, Mr. Green.
questions.explanation: The first blank needs an adjective to describe the subject 'you'. The second blank needs a comparative adjective to compare the amount of mistakes, and 'mistakes' is countable, so 'fewer' is appropriate.

questions.text: John began to learn French last month. <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'So did + subject' is used to express that someone else did the same thing.

questions.text: The bridge <blank> this photo was taken was built last year.
questions.explanation: 'Where' introduces a relative clause, indicating the location 'this photo was taken'.

questions.text:
-- I telephoned you this morning, but you <blank> in.
-- Sorry, I <blank> to the bookshop.
questions.explanation: The first blank requires past tense. The second blank describes an action completed before 'telephoned', so past perfect tense is needed.

questions.text: <blank> of the students in the class <blank> girls.
questions.explanation: 'Two thirds' is the correct way to express the fraction. The subject is plural, so 'are' should be used.

questions.text:
--Excuse me. Could you tell me <blank> some stamps?
-- Yes. There is a post office on Xinhua Road.
questions.explanation: This is an indirect question, so the word order should be 'subject + verb'. 'Where' is more appropriate.

questions.text: The girl was seen <blank> computer games in the Internet bar.
questions.explanation: 'See somebody doing something' is a fixed expression.

questions.text: Don’t put off today’s work till tomorrow. This means today’s work <blank> today.
questions.explanation: Since the work is done by someone else, the passive voice 'must be done' is needed.

questions.text:
-- Hello! May I speak to Mr. Smith, please?
--<blank>
questions.explanation: 'Hold on, please' means asking someone to wait on the phone.

questions.text:
-- I lost my new watch on the bus yesterday morning.
-- <blank>
questions.explanation: 'I'm sorry to hear that' is used to express sympathy.

questions.text: While <blank>, they talk about the music, weather and traffic. DJs also play music at clubs, dances, restaurants, and weddings.
questions.explanation: 'On the air' means broadcasting.

questions.text: DJs need <blank> voices, with good timing and pronunciation, and a strong grasp of correct grammar.
questions.explanation: 'Pleasant' is an adjective that modifies 'voices'.

questions.text: DJs should have formal training in broadcasting from a college or technical school. Courses in English, public speaking, drama, and computer science are useful. Hobbies <blank> sports and music are also helpful.
questions.explanation: 'Such as' introduces examples.

questions.text:
—Do you know <blank> girl over there?
—Yes, she likes playing <blank> basketball a lot.
questions.explanation: The first blank refers to a specific girl, so 'a' is appropriate. 'Basketball' is a sport and doesn't need an article, so '/' is appropriate.

questions.text: The story is <blank>interesting <blank>everybody likes it very much.
questions.explanation: 'So...that' is a structure that means 'to such a degree that'.

questions.text: The best way to learn new words is by <blank> English magazines.
questions.explanation: After the preposition 'by', we should use gerund form.

questions.text:
— I think it's necessary to learn how to work in groups.
—I agree. Sometimes it's even <blank>than grades.
questions.explanation: Compared to grades, working in groups can be 'more important'.

questions.text: Hurry up! Some <blank> and <blank> are on sale in the supermarket.
questions.explanation: Since the sentence is saying 'some' and 'are', both should be plural.

questions.text: <blank> fun the Water Festival is!
questions.explanation: This is an exclamation. The correct exclamation is 'How + adj. + S + V!'.

questions.text:
—I don`t have a partner to play table tennis with.
—Why <blank> a sports club to practice a lot?
questions.explanation: 'Why don't you do sth' is a common structure to give advice.

questions.text: David, <blank> you please sweep the floor and take out the trash?
questions.explanation: 'Could you please' is a polite way to ask someone to do something.

questions.text: It takes several weeks <blank> the task.
questions.explanation: 'It takes sb some time to do sth' is a common structure.

questions.text:
—These oranges look different and they are sweet.
—Right,they <blank> here from Thailand yesterday.
questions.explanation: The oranges were brought from Thailand, so it's passive voice. Also, 'yesterday' indicates that the event happened in the past, so we should use past tense.

questions.text: I <blank> you every success in the future.
questions.explanation: The sentence means 'I wish you every success in the future.' Wish is appropriate here.

questions.text: <blank> you do, I will be on your side.
questions.explanation: Whatever means 'no matter what'. The sentence means 'No matter what you do, I will be on your side.'

questions.text: After the rebuilding our school is becoming <blank>.
questions.explanation: To describe something is becoming increasingly beautiful, we should use 'more and more + adjective'.

questions.text: All the students in Class 5 will climb the mountain if it <blank> rain tomorrow.
questions.explanation: It is a conditional clause. The main clause uses future tense, so the if-clause should use present simple tense.

questions.text: Please don’t forget <blank> the room while I am away in Beijing.
questions.explanation: The sentence pattern is 'forget to do something'.

questions.text:
--Let’s go to the West Hill Park by taxi.
 -- Oh, it is not far away from here. We <blank> take a taxi.
questions.explanation: Needn't means 'don't have to'.

questions.text: I <blank> e-mails to my pen pal when Susan called me last night.
questions.explanation: The sentence uses 'when' to describe a past continuous action interrupted by another action in the past.

questions.text: Song Zuying’s voice is so sweet and her songs <blank> very beautiful.
questions.explanation: Sound is a linking verb that means 'to seem'.

questions.text: It’s difficult to live in a foreign country, <blank> if you can’t understand the language there.
questions.explanation: Especially means 'particularly'.

questions.text: — I’m going back to see my parents this afternoon. —<blank>

choices.D: Give my best wishes to them.

questions.explanation: This is a context question. According to the context, we should choose D.

questions.text: Reading can increase your words. When you read, you will find words repeat(重复) <blank> and build up your vocabulary quickly.
questions.explanation: The subject is 'words', which is plural, so we should use the plural reflexive pronoun 'themselves'.

questions.text:
—<blank> the soldiers are very tired, <blank>they keep on working.
 — They are great. We must learn from them.
questions.explanation: Though means 'although'. In this sentence, though indicates a contrast.  'Though...,...' is also correct.

questions.text:
— Sorry for being late again.
 — <blank>here on time next time, or you’ll be punished.
questions.explanation: This is an imperative sentence, so we should use the verb's base form.

questions.text: The young man came riding full speed down the road on his bicycle. <blank>it was!
questions.explanation: What + a/an + (adjective) + noun! How + (adjective/adverb) + subject + verb!

questions.text: He could hardly believe her words, <blank>?
questions.explanation: When the statement contains negative words, we should use positive form in the question tag. Here, 'hardly' is negative, so the answer should be A.

questions.text: Look! <blank> woman over there is our English teacher.
questions.explanation: The definite article 'the' is used because the speaker and listener both know which woman is being referred to.

questions.text: Mr. Li has three daughters but <blank> of them lives with him.
questions.explanation: 'None' is used because it refers to more than two people.

questions.text: If you have drunken a bottle of water, you may put the empty plastic bottle into <blank>.
questions.explanation: Plastic bottles are recyclable waste.

questions.text:
—Tom, haven't you helped your parents do the housework <blank>?
—Yes, I've helped them wash the dishes <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Yet' is used in questions to ask if something has happened, and 'already' is used to indicate that something has happened before now.

questions.text: <blank> our country becomes, <blank> the people will be.
questions.explanation: The structure 'the + comparative, the + comparative' is used to show that as one thing changes, another thing changes in proportion.

questions.text: I left school in 2016, and since then I <blank> in Beijing.
questions.explanation: The present perfect tense 'have worked' is used because the action started in the past and continues to the present.

questions.text: I always feel tired and sleepy at this time of the day. I want to avoid <blank>.
questions.explanation: The gerund 'driving' is used after the verb 'avoid'.

questions.text:
—Do you know when the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge <blank>?
—Yes. In 2018.
questions.explanation: The passive voice 'was built' is used because the bridge was built by someone.

questions.text: I feel very hungry, <blank> I want to get something to eat there.
questions.explanation: 'And' is used to connect two related ideas.

questions.text:
—Have you decided <blank> tomorrow?
—Yes. At the school gate.
questions.explanation: 'Where to meet' is a more concise and grammatically correct way to express the idea of deciding on a meeting location.

questions.text:
-- Lucy, please show <blank> your new e-dictionary.
-- OK. Here you are.
questions.explanation: The object pronoun 'me' is needed after the verb 'show'.

questions.text: Father’s Day is <blank> June 22nd this year.
questions.explanation: We use 'on' with specific dates.

questions.text: Mt. Qomolangma is <blank> mountain in the world.
questions.explanation: The superlative form 'the highest' is used to compare Mt. Qomolangma with all other mountains in the world.

questions.text:
-- <blank> did you spend your winter vacation?
-- In England.
questions.explanation: 'Where' is used to ask about the location.

questions.text:
-- I’m afraid I can’t finish <blank> the report this week.
-- Don’t worry. I’ll give you a hand.
questions.explanation: The verb 'finish' is followed by a gerund (verb + -ing).

questions.text:
-- How can we get to Water Cube?
-- Sorry, I don’t know, either. Why not look it up on the <blank>?
questions.explanation: You would look up a location on a map.

questions.text:
-- Where is Tom?
-- He <blank> the Olympic Torch Relay in the street now.
questions.explanation: The present continuous tense ('is watching') is used to describe an action happening now.

questions.text: Our teacher often tells us <blank> the window before we leave.
questions.explanation: The structure 'tell someone to do something' is used.

questions.text: Little Mary is only three years old, but she <blank> read story books.
questions.explanation: 'Can' is used to express ability.

questions.text:
-- Is there <blank> special in today’s newspaper?
-- I’m afraid not.
questions.explanation: 'Anything' is used in questions.

questions.text: You’d better <blank> right now, or you will be late for the concert.
questions.explanation: 'Had better' is followed by the base form of the verb.

questions.text: The Art Festival <blank> in our town every year.
questions.explanation: The passive voice ('is held') is used because the Art Festival is being held, not holding something.

questions.text: I will drive the children to school if it <blank> tomorrow.
questions.explanation: In conditional sentences with 'if', we use the present simple tense to talk about the future.

questions.text: Many people move to the countryside <blank> they enjoy the quiet life there.
questions.explanation: 'Because' introduces a reason.

questions.text: Tom helped a lost child, so he <blank> home late last night.
questions.explanation: 'Got back' means returned.

questions.text: Kevin <blank> Chinese for more than 20 years. Now he speaks it quite well.
questions.explanation: The present perfect tense ('has learned') is used to describe an action that started in the past and continues to the present.

questions.text:
-- Do you know <blank> this weekend?
-- We plan to visit the Science Museum.

choices.A: what we are going to do
choices.B: what are we going to do
choices.C: what we were going to do
choices.D: what were we going to do

questions.explanation: This is an indirect question, so the word order should be subject + verb.

questions.text:
-- Would you like to go to see the film Iron Man with me?
-- <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Yes, I'd love to' is a polite way to accept an invitation.
